Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Integration: Supporting Climate Modeling Over Named Data Networking (NDN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Named Data Networking (NDN) is an instance of Information Centric Networking (ICN). Unlike IP, NDN focuses on content (the what) rather than hosts (the where). In NDN users simply request content by name rather than its location, and the network locates and retrieves signed content from anywhere, including the publisher, a network cache or a nearby user. The ability to specify content by name and retrieve the nearest copy is of great benefit to Big Data applications by seamlessly locating related data and speeding up retrieval of large datasets, especially in collaborative environments.

In this project, networking researchers at the Computer Science and Atmospheric Sciences departments at Colorado State University will work together to integrate NDN with the Global Cloud Resolving Model (GCRM) application. GCRM simulates the global atmosphere using a grid fine enough to crudely resolve the larger individual clouds. This application typically generates terabyte to petabyte scale datasets. GCRMs are currently under development at several modeling centers in the U.S. and abroad.

Project contributions include a seamless integration of NDN with researchers' work flow through integration with the file system, versioning control, the design of appropriate name spaces to facilitate seamless data discovery, building efficient collaboration and sharing environments and ensuring data integrity. To ensure smooth transition to the new environment, the project builds translators between existing and NDN-appropriate formats. Instrumented NDN routers are deployed across three campuses to support testing and engagement in a continuous feedback loop with researchers to improve the network and the tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science advances become increasingly dependent on online data sharing. Scientific discoveries and measurement data are published online, which are then retrieved by scientists around the world to conduct further research. it is highly desirable to scientists in all domains to make the process of data publication, discovery, and retrieval, which we broadly call as data management, be easy-to-use, efficient, scalable, resilient against failures, and secured for data integrity and provenance. The reality today is far from that ideal. In today's online science data sharing, the data management problem is rapidly approaching critical levels. The problem is not unique to big data science such as high-energy physics and climate modeling, where data volume is an obvious challenge, but affects other science domains as well. Although a number of efforts have been devoted to make online science datasets available, the solutions so far remain ad-hoc, piecemeal, and serving specific domains only.

In this project we applied Named Data networking (NDN) to vastly simplify scientific data management. NDN is one of three recent Future Internet Architecture (FIA) projects. NDN changes the communication paradigm from host-centric to name-centric. In other words, NDN addresses the content, not the hosts in a communication network. The benefits of a name-centric network are substantial: the user only needs to specify the name of the desired content and the network will fetch it from the most convenient location, not just the content publisher. This allows content retrieval from caches, replicas and even other users who have recently accessed the content. Contentt in NDN is also digitally signed so the user can always verify the integrity, authenticity and provenance of any retrieved content.

We applied NDN in this project to manage Climate and High-Energy Physics data. We built a high-speed testbed (10Gbps) and about 100TB of storage using nodes deployed at Colorado State University, Caltech, LBNL and a research institute in Korea (KISTI). Using the testbed we implemented a catalog for publishing, searching and retrieval of scientific data. We demonstrated how the system takes advantage of several NDN features such as retrieval from the nearest location, authenticated publishing, easy search and efficient retrieval form multiple replicas. We also design automatic translators to convert standard dataset names to hierarchical NDN names. The system was demonstrated with climate (CMIP5) data and High-Energy Physics (Atlas) data. The results met our expectations: NDN not only simplified this important application, but encouraged name standardization across science domains by offering real gains in data management.

Looking at the future, we believe that NDN is not only a credible solution to existing scientific data management problems today, but one that promises to simplify and unify various disjoint approaches that exist today resulting in significant savings across science domains.
